heading: digital music: no time soon
subheading: a new report from jupiter communications concludes that digital music is a long way off as a mainstream music delivery vehicle. but in the meantime, labels should learn from mp3.
author: wired news report
text: when will most folks get their music online rather than on disc? not anytime soon, according to a report released tuesday by research firm jupiter communications. only 3 percent of online consumers will purchase downloaded digital music by 2003."the music industry's best efforts still fall short when it comes to preparing for the day when digital music distribution is commonplace," said lucas graves, an analyst in jupiter's web technology strategies, in a statement.read wired news' ongoing mp3 coveragebrowse webmonkey's mp3 guide- - - - - -"companies that focus on strict security measures rather than maximizing the value proposition will lose out," he said.jupiter's report concluded that digital music distribution will not emerge as a mainstream consumer technology until it overcomes major obstacles.if recording companies don't adapt to the inherent insecurity of digital distribution, they risk paying the price when the technology goes mainstream over the next five years, graves warned.his advice to record labels: embrace mp3 as a promotional vehicle while the industry settles on formats that offer greater piracy protection.the secure digital music initiative, a tool for implementing such measures, is due to arrive in its final, ratified form on thursday.the report predicts that until digital music becomes mainstream, mp3 will remain the dominant format through 2000.
